DOCNAME: AHMADI, SABERDJAN AND SABERDJAN v. LITHUANIA
TEXT: The first applicant , PERSON , was born in DATE . The second applicant , GPE SABERDJAN , was born in DATE . The third applicant , PERSON , is the second applicant 's son , born in DATE . All CARDINAL were born in GPE . The applicants are represented before the ORG by Mr. PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The first applicant fled from GPE in DATE and illegally entered GPE via Belarus without any valid identification papers . She applied for political asylum in GPE , which was refused on the ground that she had no established family links in GPE and that her fear of persecution in GPE had been unsubstantiated . On DATE the Minister of the ORG decided to expel the first applicant from GPE . No time - limit or country of destination was specified in the expulsion order . The court proceedings brought by the applicant against the above decisions were unsuccessful .

By reference to LAW ( see the ' Relevant domestic law ' part below ) , on CARDINAL DATE the interior authorities held that the first applicant could face persecution in GPE and decided to clarify her identity and re - examine her status in GPE on account of the persistent state of unrest in GPE and “ in accordance with the principle of non - refoulement . ”
On DATE the first applicant applied to the interior authorities to leave GPE . She obtained an NORP passport from ORG in GPE and voluntarily left GPE on DATE . It appears that she now lives in GPE .
Proceedings concerning the second and third applicants

In DATE the second and third applicants fled from GPE . They illegally entered GPE via Belarus without any documents and immediately requested asylum . On DATE the Minister of the ORG refused asylum on the ground that there was no substantiated fear of their persecution in GPE . In the same decision the Minister decided to expel the second applicant and his son from GPE . No time - limit or destination was specified . The second applicant brought court proceedings concerning the above decisions , but to no avail .
On DATE ORG granted asylum to the second applicant 's brother and his family .

By reference to LAW , on CARDINAL DATE the interior authorities held that the second and third applicants could face persecution in GPE and decided to clarify their identity and re - examine their status in GPE on account of the persistent state of unrest in GPE and “ in accordance with the principle of non - refoulement . ”

The second and third applicants applied for temporary residence on “ humanitarian grounds ” ( see the ' Relevant domestic law ' part below ) . By a decision of DATE they were issued temporary residence permits for DATE , pursuant to LAW , because of the danger to their lives and health in GPE . In that decision it was noted that the second applicant had no valid identification documents , but that he had been assisted by the NORP immigration authorities in applying to ORG in GPE for an NORP passport . The second applicant was requested to present a passport so that his and his son 's temporary residence permits could be renewed after DATE .
Article CARDINAL of the Refugees Act stipulates that a rejected asylum seeker for whom an expulsion order has been issued can not be expelled if his life could be endangered as a result .
Pursuant to LAW , an expulsion order can be suspended on “ humanitarian grounds . ” Pursuant to LAW , a rejected asylum seeker can apply for temporary residence on “ humanitarian grounds . ”
